prompts.title: Quiz Answer : Prompt Generator
prompts.content:
BEGIN PROMPT
You are an assessment-authoring assistant.  
Your task is to read the user-supplied learning material (inserted below) and return a JSON object that contains quiz-wide array of questions that conform to the schema, quality rules, and counts here.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
PLACEHOLDER for source material
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
<<<START-OF-CONTENT>>>
[[PASTE YOUR CHAPTER / ARTICLE / NOTES HERE]]
<<<END-OF-CONTENT>>>
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

============== 1  GLOBAL OUTPUT RULES ==============
â€¢ Return **exactly one JSON object**
```
[
 // array of Question objects (see Â§2)
]         
```
â€¢ Do NOT wrap the object in markdown fences or add commentary.
â€¢ Target counts (total = {{[[Number of questions at least 20 questions]]}}); scale proportionally if the material is too short:

Type	Appearance Ratio
Multiple Choice	33%
True/False	14%
Scenario	23%
Sequencing	5%
Categorizing	5%
Ranking	5%
Matching	5%
Merit/Demerit	5%
Comparison	5%

(You may optionally add categorizing, matching, merit_demerit, or comparison items; if you do, respect the schema in Â§2.)

============== 2 QUESTION OBJECT SCHEMA ==============

```json
[
{
  "type":         "multiple" | "text" | "scenario" | "ranking"
                 | "sequencing" | "categorizing" | "matching"
                 | "merit_demerit" | "comparison",

  "question":     string,                   // not used by "text"
  "text":         string,                   // only for "text"
  "scenario":     string,                   // only for "scenario"
  "options":      [string, â€¦],              // multiple, scenario, text, comparison
  "items":        [string, â€¦],              // ranking, sequencing, categorizing
  "categories":   [string, â€¦],              // categorizing
  
  // merit_demerit specific fields
  "approach":     string,                   // merit_demerit only
  "context":      string,                   // merit_demerit only
  "merits":       [string, â€¦],              // merit_demerit only
  "demerits":     [string, â€¦],              // merit_demerit only
  "recommendation": string,                 // merit_demerit only
  
  // comparison specific fields
  "option1":      string,                   // comparison only
  "option2":      string,                   // comparison only
  "criteria":     [string, â€¦],              // comparison only
  "comparison":   {                         // comparison only
    "criterion": {
      "winner": "option1" | "option2",
      "explanation": string
    }
  },
  
  // matching specific fields
  "leftItems":         [string, â€¦],              // matching only
  "rightItems":        [string, â€¦],              // matching only
  "correctMatches":    {                         // matching only
    "leftItem": "rightItem",
    ...
  },
  
  // categorizing specific fields
  "correctCategorization":   {                   // categorizing only
    "Category Name": [
      "item1",
      "item2",
      ...
    ]
  },
  
  "correct":      string,                   // multiple, scenario, text, comparison
  "correctOrder": [string, â€¦],              // ranking, sequencing
  "feedback":     string,                   // 1-2 sentences
  "StudyPoint":   string                    // â‰¤200-word takeaway
}
]
```

============== 3 QUALITY REQUIREMENTS ==============

All questions
â€“ Stem â‰¤ 25 words; each option/item â‰¤ 15 words.
â€“ feedback: why the answer/order is correct (1-2 short sentences).
â€“ StudyPoint: main concept captured in 150-200 words max, tied to the pasted material.

Type-specific
â€” multiple â€¢ 1 right + 3-4 plausible distractors; parallel wording.
â€” text   â€¢ Exactly 4 options; statement unequivocally true or false.
â€” scenario â€¢ Narrative â‰¤ 80 words; options show realistic decision errors.
â€” ranking â€¢ 4-6 items; ordering rule explicit; supply correctOrder.
â€” sequencing â€¢ 4-8 chronological or procedural steps; supply correctOrder.
â€” categorizing â€¢ Items should be categorized into provided categories; use correctCategorization object format.
â€” matching â€¢ Match leftItems with rightItems using correctMatches object format.
â€” merit_demerit â€¢ Include approach, context, merits, demerits, and recommendation fields.
â€” comparison â€¢ Include option1, option2, criteria, comparison object, and recommendation fields.

============== 4 REFERENCE EXCERPT (LIVE EXAMPLES FROM YOUR FILES) ==============
The snippet below shows one real example for every type present in your current dataset.
Mimic this structureâ€”but generate new content from the user material.

```json
[
    {                                   // â† multiple
      "type": "multiple",
      "question": "According to the chapter, what is the primary purpose of 'boiler-plate' terms?",
      "options": [
        "Fill space in contracts",
        "Provide clarity for dispute resolution",
        "Satisfy minimum length rules",
        "Protect only the seller"
      ],
      "correct": "Provide clarity for dispute resolution",
      "feedback": "Boiler-plate clauses clarify interpretation and guide dispute handling.",
      "StudyPoint": "Far from filler, boiler-plate provisionsâ€”applicable law, dispute resolution, definitionsâ€”create the legal scaffolding that prevents ambiguity and streamlines conflict resolution in complex agreements."
    },
    {                                   // â† scenario
      "type": "scenario",
      "scenario": "Hiroshi reviews a CBREâ€“Singapore contract that omits the governing-law clause.",
      "question": "Why is specifying applicable law critical?",
      "options": [
        "It sets the payment currency",
        "It governs formation and performance of the contract",
        "Only domestic deals need it",
        "It controls technical specs"
      ],
      "correct": "It governs formation and performance of the contract",
      "feedback": "Applicable-law clauses decide which legal system rules disputes.",
      "StudyPoint": "In cross-border agreements, parties name the governing law and jurisdiction to avoid forum shopping, reduce uncertainty, and ensure that any litigation or arbitration proceeds under a body of rules they understand and can price into the deal."
    },
    {                                   // â† text / true-false
      "type": "text",
      "text": "Arbitration offers privacy compared to court hearings.",
      "options": [
        "True â€“ arbitration is private",
        "False â€“ always public",
        "True â€“ but only for small claims",
        "False â€“ courts are private"
      ],
      "correct": "True â€“ arbitration is private",
      "feedback": "Arbitration keeps disputes out of public court records.",
      "StudyPoint": "Businesses select arbitration to shield sensitive commercial data, trade secrets, and reputations from the public domain. While awards can be challenged, hearings and filings generally remain confidential unless parties agree otherwise."
    },
    {                                   // â† ranking
      "type": "ranking",
      "question": "Rank spec types by seller responsibility:",
      "items": [
        "Technical spec",
        "Functional spec",
        "Performance spec",
        "Requirement spec"
      ],
      "correctOrder": [
        "Technical spec",
        "Functional spec",
        "Performance spec",
        "Requirement spec"
      ],
      "feedback": "Responsibility grows from meeting form to meeting outcome.",
      "StudyPoint": "Technical specs say 'what it must be'; requirement specs say 'what result it must achieve.' As the spec shifts toward outcomes, sellers gain freedom to innovate but shoulder full liability for fitness-for-purpose."
    },
    {                                   // â† sequencing
      "type": "sequencing",
      "question": "Order price-agreement methods from most to least competitive:",
      "items": [
        "Competitive tender",
        "Advertisement (invitation to treat)",
        "Single tender",
        "Direct negotiation"
      ],
      "correctOrder": [
        "Competitive tender",
        "Advertisement (invitation to treat)",
        "Single tender",
        "Direct negotiation"
      ],
      "feedback": "More bidders â†’ greater competition â†’ keener pricing.",
      "StudyPoint": "Competitive tenders force suppliers to sharpen bids; direct negotiations lack external pressure. Understanding this spectrum lets buyers balance price tension against speed, confidentiality, and relationship factors."
    },
    {                                   // â† categorizing
        "type": "categorizing",
        "question": "Trung is reviewing different types of dependencies for CBRE's office expansion project. Categorize the following project situations into 'Internal Dependencies' or 'External Dependencies':",
        "items": [
        "Waiting for Tokyo municipal building permits",
        "Completing electrical work before ceiling installation",
        "Receiving budget approval from Evelyn in Singapore",
        "Hiroshi finishing legal review before contract signing",
        "Obtaining fire safety certification from local authorities",
        "Tanaka completing space planning before furniture ordering"
        ],
        "categories": ["Internal Dependencies", "External Dependencies"],
        "correctCategorization": {
        "Internal Dependencies": [
            "Completing electrical work before ceiling installation",
            "Hiroshi finishing legal review before contract signing",
            "Tanaka completing space planning before furniture ordering"
        ],
        "External Dependencies": [
            "Waiting for Tokyo municipal building permits",
            "Receiving budget approval from Evelyn in Singapore",
            "Obtaining fire safety certification from local authorities"
        ]
        },
        "feedback": "Internal dependencies are activities entirely under the project manager's control within the team, such as sequencing internal work or completing internal reviews. External dependencies rely on entities outside the project's direct control, such as government approvals, external stakeholder decisions, or regulatory certifications."
    },
    {                                   // â† merit_demerit
        "type": "merit_demerit",
        "question": "Trung is deciding between using Activity on Arrow (AOA) versus Activity on Node (AON) network diagrams for CBRE's complex office renovation project. Evaluate the merits and demerits of AOA networks:",
        "approach": "Activity on Arrow (AOA) Network Diagrams",
        "context": "Large-scale office renovation with multiple contractors and complex dependencies",
        "merits": [
        "Shows clear chronological flow between activities",
        "Familiar format for experienced construction managers",
        "Good for projects with many sequential dependencies",
        "Integrates well with traditional project management approaches"
        ],
        "demerits": [
        "Requires dummy activities to maintain logical correctness",
        "More complex to construct and modify",
        "Harder for team members to understand quickly",
        "Difficult to show non-standard dependency relationships"
        ],
        "recommendation": "Consider AON networks instead",
        "feedback": "While AOA networks have historical precedent and work well for sequential projects, their complexity and need for dummy activities make them less practical for modern project management. AON networks are generally easier to construct, understand, and modify, making them more suitable for complex projects with diverse stakeholders like CBRE's renovation."
    },
    {                                   // â† comparison
        "type": "comparison",
        "question": "Trung needs to choose between Gantt charts and Network diagrams for presenting the office renovation timeline to Evelyn and the Singapore team. Compare these two planning tools:",
        "option1": "Gantt Charts",
        "option2": "Network Diagrams",
        "criteria": [
        "Visual clarity for non-technical stakeholders",
        "Ability to show activity dependencies",
        "Ease of understanding project timeline",
        "Capability to identify critical path",
        "Suitability for progress tracking",
        "Effectiveness for resource planning"
        ],
        "comparison": {
        "Visual clarity for non-technical stakeholders": {
            "winner": "Gantt Charts",
            "explanation": "Gantt charts provide intuitive timeline visualization that executives can understand quickly"
        },
        "Ability to show activity dependencies": {
            "winner": "Network Diagrams",
            "explanation": "Network diagrams explicitly show all dependency relationships between activities"
        },
        "Ease of understanding project timeline": {
            "winner": "Gantt Charts",
            "explanation": "Time-based horizontal format makes project duration and scheduling immediately apparent"
        },
        "Capability to identify critical path": {
            "winner": "Network Diagrams",
            "explanation": "Network diagrams clearly highlight critical path and slack calculations"
        },
        "Suitability for progress tracking": {
            "winner": "Gantt Charts",
            "explanation": "Progress bars and milestone markers make status tracking visually obvious"
        },
        "Effectiveness for resource planning": {
            "winner": "Gantt Charts",
            "explanation": "Resource allocation over time is easier to visualize and manage with Gantt format"
        }
        },
        "recommendation": "Use Gantt charts for executive presentation, network diagrams for detailed planning",
        "feedback": "Gantt charts excel at communicating schedules to stakeholders and tracking progress, while network diagrams are superior for detailed dependency analysis and critical path identification. The best approach often combines both tools: network diagrams for initial planning and analysis, then Gantt charts for communication and monitoring."
    },
    {                                   // â† matching
        "type": "matching",
        "question": "Trung is training his team on project planning tools and techniques. Match each planning tool with its primary purpose in the CBRE office renovation project:",
        "leftItems": [
        "Work Breakdown Structure (WBS)",
        "Network Diagrams",
        "Gantt Charts",
        "Flowcharts",
        "Resource Levelling",
        "Critical Path Method"
        ],
        "rightItems": [
        "Visualizing timeline and parallel activities for stakeholder communication",
        "Breaking project into manageable, measurable components",
        "Identifying longest sequence of dependent activities",
        "Balancing resource allocation to prevent conflicts",
        "Mapping general process flow and identifying dependencies",
        "Calculating earliest and latest activity start/finish times"
        ],
        "correctMatches": {
        "Work Breakdown Structure (WBS)": "Breaking project into manageable, measurable components",
        "Network Diagrams": "Calculating earliest and latest activity start/finish times",
        "Gantt Charts": "Visualizing timeline and parallel activities for stakeholder communication",
        "Flowcharts": "Mapping general process flow and identifying dependencies",
        "Resource Levelling": "Balancing resource allocation to prevent conflicts",
        "Critical Path Method": "Identifying longest sequence of dependent activities"
        },
        "feedback": "Each planning tool serves specific purposes in project management. WBS structures the work, flowcharts map processes, network diagrams provide detailed scheduling analysis, Gantt charts communicate timelines, resource levelling optimizes allocation, and critical path method identifies schedule-critical activities. Understanding when to use each tool is essential for effective project planning."
    }
]
```

============== 5 VALIDATION CHECKS ==============
â€¢ No duplicate stems or option text.
â€¢ Every correct value, correctOrder element, correctCategorization value, and correctMatches entry must appear in its respective list.
â€¢ StudyPoint â‰¤ 150 words.
â€¢ JSON passes a linter.

============== 6 DELIVERY INSTRUCTIONS ==============
Return only the final JSON object described in Â§1â€”no extra text, no markdown.
Output shall be in the same language as input
END PROMPT

prompts.title: Book Explainer (NotebookLM)
prompts.content:
You are a seasoned professor teaching complete beginners. Your student is brand-new to the subject, so every explanation must be crystal clear.

For each page of the material, produce:
â€¢ Page #<number>: <Explanation>

Each explanation should:
1. Use a relatable analogy or comparison to make abstract ideas concrete.
2. Define any technical term (jargon) in plain, everyday language.
3. Break concepts down into simple steps or examples.

Example:
Page #1: In this page, we compare a computerâ€™s CPU to the human brainâ€”just as your brain processes thoughts, the CPU processes instructions. A â€œbitâ€ is like a tiny light switch that can be ON or OFF, representing 1 or 0 in computingâ€¦

prompts.title: AnkiCards (Multiple QA)
prompts.content:
You are tasked with creating educational flashcards in a specific format for Anki import. Follow these guidelines: ## Format Requirements: - Generate flashcards as plain text format for direct .txt import to Anki - Each flashcard should be clearly separated with "---" dividers - Use HTML formatting: ``, `
`, `` for proper Anki display - Questions should be multiple choice with options A, B, C, D - Structure each card as: ``` [Question content 1] [Answer content 1] [Study point - Key learning concept 1] [Question content 2] [Answer content 2] [Study point - Key learning concept 2] ..... ``` ## Mathematical Formula Rendering: **For modern Anki with MathJax support:** - Use `\(` and `\)` for inline mathematics: `\(x^2 + y^2 = z^2\)` - Use `\[` and `\]` for display mathematics: `\[\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}\]` - Use `$$` and `$$` for display math when needed: `$$\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i$$` **Examples of proper LaTeX formatting:** - Fractions: `\(\frac{numerator}{denominator}\)` - Square roots: `\(\sqrt{x}\)` or `\(\sqrt[n]{x}\)` - Superscripts: `\(x^2\)` or `\(e^{-x}\)` - Subscripts: `\(x_1\)` or `\(H_2O\)` - Greek letters: `\(\alpha\)`, `\(\beta\)`, `\(\pi\)` - Summations: `\(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\)` - Integrals: `\(\int_{a}^{b} f(x)dx\)` ## Content Structure: ### Question Field: - Start with `[Question text]

` - Include mathematical formulas using proper LaTeX syntax - List 4 multiple choice options using format: ``` A) [Option 1]
B) [Option 2]
C) [Option 3]
D) [Option 4] ``` ### Answer Field: - Format: `Answer: [Letter]` â€“ [Explanation] - Include mathematical explanations with proper LaTeX formatting - Provide clear, concise explanation of why the answer is correct ### Study Point Field: - 3-4 sentence summary of the key learning concept, address what, why, how with good explanation - Include relevant formulas using LaTeX syntax - Focus on the main educational takeaway from the question - Each sentence shall be separated by HTML break `

` - At the end of study point include 2 most important keywords in both EN/JP ## Example Output with Math: ``` What is the formula for calculating the present value of an annuity? / å¹´é‡‘ã®ç¾åœ¨ä¾¡å€¤ã‚’è¨ˆç®—ã™ã‚‹å…¬å¼ã¯ä½•ã§ã™ã‹ï¼Ÿ

D) \(PMT = \frac{PV \times r}{1-(1+r)^{-n}}\) / \(PMT = \frac{PV \times r}{1-(1+r)^{-n}}\) Answer: A â€“ The present value of an annuity formula \(PV = \frac{PMT \times (1-(1+r)^{-n})}{r}\) calculates the current worth of a series of equal payments. / å¹´é‡‘ã®ç¾åœ¨ä¾¡å€¤å…¬å¼ \(PV = \frac{PMT \times (1-(1+r)^{-n})}{r}\) ã¯ã€ä¸€é€£ã®ç­‰é¡æ”¯æ‰•ã„ã®ç¾åœ¨ä¾¡å€¤ã‚’è¨ˆç®—ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚ Present value of annuity represents the current worth of a stream of equal future payments discounted at a specific interest rate. / å¹´é‡‘ã®ç¾åœ¨ä¾¡å€¤ã¯ã€ç‰¹å®šã®åˆ©ç‡ã§å‰²ã‚Šå¼•ã‹ã‚ŒãŸå°†æ¥ã®ç­‰é¡æ”¯æ‰•ã„ã®æµã‚Œã®ç¾åœ¨ä¾¡å€¤ã‚’è¡¨ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

The formula accounts for the time value of money by discounting each future payment back to present value. / ã“ã®å…¬å¼ã¯ã€å„å°†æ¥æ”¯æ‰•ã„ã‚’ç¾åœ¨ä¾¡å€¤ã«å‰²ã‚Šå¼•ãã“ã¨ã§è²¨å¹£ã®æ™‚é–“ä¾¡å€¤ã‚’è€ƒæ…®ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

This calculation is essential for investment analysis and loan amortization schedules. / ã“ã®è¨ˆç®—ã¯æŠ•è³‡åˆ†æã‚„ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒ³ã®å„Ÿå´ã‚¹ã‚±ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã«ä¸å¯æ¬ ã§ã™ã€‚

**Keywords:** Present Value / ç¾åœ¨ä¾¡å€¤, Annuity / å¹´é‡‘ ``` ## Language Requirements: - ALL text must be bilingual: English / Japanese - Format each sentence as: "English text / Japanese text" - Apply this to questions, answer choices, explanations, and study points - Mathematical expressions remain the same in both languages - Maintain parallel sentence structure between languages - Use natural, professional language in both English and Japanese ## Content Input: Analyze the following content to create flashcards: ``` [[Paste your content here]] ``` ## Your Task: Create [[How many Flashcards?]] flashcards covering entire contents. prompts.title: GitHub App Development Prompt
prompts.content:
Replace [username], [repository-name], and [brand color] with your specific values before using this prompt.

I need you to create a complete GitHub application with the following requirements:

 Basic Setup
- Create an `index.html` file that works as the main interface
- Include a `database.json` file to store data in hierarchical categories
- Deploy on GitHub repository: `github/[username]/[repository-name]`
- Add token authentication - users must enter a valid token before they can edit data

 Core Features
- Search Function: Real-time search with fuzzy matching that works with any language (English, Vietnamese, Chinese, Japanese, etc.). Support multiple keywords separated by commas.
- Display: Show data as collapsible thumbnail cards organized by categories. Make thumbnails thin/compact to fit many on screen.
- Click to View: When users click a thumbnail, show a popup with full content and "Copy" button.
- Smart Clipboard: For prompts with `{{placeholder}}` text, add a "Replace with Clipboard" button that substitutes the placeholder with current clipboard content.
- Edit Mode: After token validation, allow users to add, edit, delete categories and items through the interface.

 Visual Design
- Use [brand color] as primary color (e.g., jungle green 228B22)
- Add checkered pattern background with glass morphism effects
- High contrast text for readability
- Thick, glossy borders around elements

 Critical Bug Prevention
1. Unicode Support: Ensure all text input/output works correctly with non-Latin characters (Chinese, Japanese, Vietnamese, Arabic, etc.)
2. Search Result Accuracy: When displaying search results, maintain correct item IDs so clicking thumbnails shows the right content
3. Proper Encoding: Use UTF-8 encoding for all GitHub API operations

 Expected Deliverables
- Complete `index.html` file with embedded CSS and JavaScript
- Sample `database.json` with hierarchical structure
- Working GitHub API integration for read/write operations
- Responsive design that works on mobile and desktop

Important: Test the app with non-English text and verify search results match correctly when clicked. The application should be production-ready and deployable immediately to GitHub Pages.

prompts.title: Python App (General)
prompts.content:
I need you to create a complete desktop Python [Short Problem / Software Purpose] application with full CRUD capabilities, robust attachment handling, and a multi-tab GUI:

Project Structure  
- All files live in a single folder:  
  - `app.py` â€” main application entry point  
  - `database.db` â€” SQLite database file (empty schema)  
  - `temp_database.json` â€” staging area for changes (empty JSON)  
  - `attachments/` directory for uploaded media and other files (empty)  

Database Schema (in `database.db`)  
- **issues** table:  
  - `id` (INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT)  
  - `title` (TEXT, required)  
  - `description` (TEXT, required)  
  - `status` (TEXT; e.g., â€œOpenâ€, â€œIn Progressâ€, â€œClosedâ€)  
  - `priority` (TEXT; e.g., â€œLowâ€, â€œMediumâ€, â€œHighâ€)  
  - `assignee` (TEXT)  
  - `created_at` (DATETIME)  
  - `updated_at` (DATETIME)  
- **attachments** table:  
  - `id` (INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT)  
  - `issue_id` (INTEGER, foreign key â†’ issues.id)  
  - `filename` (TEXT)  
  - `filepath` (TEXT)  
  - `uploaded_at` (DATETIME)  
- **audio_notes** table:  
  - `id` (INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT)  
  - `issue_id` (INTEGER, foreign key â†’ issues.id)  
  - `filename` (TEXT)  
  - `filepath` (TEXT)  
  - `recorded_at` (DATETIME)  

Core Features & CRUD Operations  

1. **Create**  
   - **Log Issue** (Issue-Logger tab): GUI form fields for title, description, status, priority, assignee, plus â€œAdd Attachmentsâ€ and â€œRecord Audio Noteâ€ buttons.  
     - On â€œCreate,â€ write into `temp_database.json`; on â€œSave,â€ INSERT into `issues`, `attachments`, and `audio_notes` tables and clear staging.  
   - **Attach Files**: Select multiple files â†’ save to `attachments/issue_<ID>/`; record file paths in `attachments` table.  
   - **Record Audio Note**: Record via microphone â†’ save to `attachments/issue_<ID>/audio_<timestamp>.wav`, record in `audio_notes` table.  

2. **Read**  
   - **Issue Viewer** (Issue-Viewer tab): Display all issues as scrollable, collapsible cards showing ID, title, status, priority.  
   - **Detail Popup**: Clicking a card opens a popup with full description, assignee, timestamps, attachment thumbnails/previews, and audio playback controls.  
   - **Download/Open** attachments via buttons; **Play/Pause** audio notes.  

3. **Update** (Edit Mode â€“ all fields and media fully editable)  
   - In **Edit Mode**, every field (title, description, status, priority, assignee), attachments, and audio notes can be:  
     - **Edited** (modify text fields)  
     - **Added** (new attachments via file dialog or â€œPaste Image from Clipboardâ€ button; new audio via â€œRecord Audio Noteâ€)  
     - **Deleted** (remove attachments or audio entries)  
   - Changes go into `temp_database.json`; on â€œSave Changes,â€ UPDATE tables and clear staging.  

4. **Delete**  
   - **Issue**: Confirm then DELETE issue and all its attachments/audio (files + DB rows).  
   - **Attachment**: Delete single file + DB record without affecting issue.  
   - **Audio Note**: Delete single audio file + DB record.  

5. **Search & Filter**  
   - **Search Issues** tab: Real-time fuzzy search over titles & descriptions (multi-keyword, multilingual).  
   - Filters for status, priority, assignee, and date range.  
   - Display results as cards with quick-view and link to detail popup.  

6. **Dashboard**  
   - **Dashboard** tab: Summary widgetsâ€”total issues, counts by status/priority, recent activity timeline, and charts of issue trends.  

7. **Smart Clipboard Replacement**  
   - Wherever text contains `{{placeholder}}`, show â€œReplace with Clipboardâ€ button to swap in current clipboard.  
   - **Paste Image from Clipboard**: In both Create and Edit modes, allow pasting image data directly into attachments; show that image in preview panel.  

Visual & UX  
- Use [brand color] as primary UI accent.  
- Subtle checkered-pattern background with glass-morphism panels.  
- High-contrast text; thick, glossy borders.  
- Responsive layout adapting to window resize.  
- Tabbed interface (e.g., Tkinter Notebook or PyQt QTabWidget) with four tabs:  
  1. **Log Issue**  
  2. **Issue Viewer**  
  3. **Search Issues**  
  4. **Dashboard**  

Additional GUI Instructions  
- All panels, lists, and controls must be **expandable** and **dynamically stretch** to fill the window when resized.  
- Ensure **minimum visible sizes**: main text font size = 13 pt, button labels = 12 pt, input fields = 12 pt.  
- Provide **tooltips** on hover for all icons and buttons.  
- Ensure **keyboard navigation** support (tab order, focus highlights).  
- **Attachment Preview Panel**: When an attachment is an image, display its thumbnail on the right side of the GUI.  

Best Practices for a Good GUI  
1. **Keep it Simple**: Only show essentialsâ€”avoid clutter.  
2. **High Visibility**: Use sufficient contrast and clear labels.  
3. **Predictable Layout**: Group related controls logically; maintain consistency across tabs.  
4. **Immediate Feedback**: Show loading indicators, success confirmations, and error messages inline.  
5. **Accessibility**: Support screen readers, high-contrast mode, and scalable fonts.  

Launch Scripts & Setup Files  
- `requirements.txt` â€” pin all Python dependencies.  
- `init_db.py` â€” script to create and initialize `database.db` schema.  
- `setup.py` â€” package metadata & entry points for pip installation.  
- `run.bat` (Windows) & `run.sh` (macOS/Linux) â€” convenience scripts to install deps, init DB, and launch `app.py`.  

Unicode & Encoding  
- Full UTF-8 support so non-Latin scripts (Chinese, Japanese, Vietnamese, Arabic, etc.) display, store, and search correctly.  

Deliverables  
- `app.py` with complete logic: GUI (tabbed), CRUD, search/filtering, dashboard widgets, clipboard/image paste & preview, audio recording/playback, staging and commit from `temp_database.json` to `database.db`.  
- `requirements.txt`, `init_db.py`, `setup.py`, and `run.bat`/`run.sh`.  
- Empty `database.db` schema and blank `temp_database.json`.  
- Empty `attachments/` folder.  
- README with dependency installation and instructions to launch on Windows, macOS, and Linux.  

Testing Requirements  
- Verify create/read/update/delete for issues, attachments, and audio notes in each tab and mode.  
- Confirm attachments (including pasted images) save to and load from correct `issue_<ID>` subfolders.  
- Confirm audio notes record, play back, and delete correctly.  
- Test search, filter, and dashboard accuracy with non-English content.  
- Test resizing: ensure all controls expand and remain legible at various window sizes.  
- Test clipboard text and image replacement in all relevant areas.  

This application should be production-ready and launchable directly from its folder.

prompts.title: FlaskPython-General
prompts.content:
Unified Development Guidelines for LLM Prompting
Core Engineering Principles
DRY + KISS + SOLID Foundation
All development must adhere to these fundamental principles:
DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself)

Eliminate code duplication through functions, components, and modules
Create reusable utilities and shared configurations
Use template inheritance and component libraries

KISS (Keep It Simple, Stupid)

Prefer simple, readable solutions over complex architectures
Minimize dependencies and external libraries
Write self-documenting code with clear naming conventions

SOLID Principles

Single Responsibility: Each module/component has one clear purpose
Open/Closed: Extensible without modification of existing code
Liskov Substitution: Derived classes must be substitutable for base classes
Interface Segregation: Many specific interfaces over one general interface
Dependency Inversion: Depend on abstractions, not concretions

Architecture Framework: MAFIAS + SBMF + CRYSTAL + RSR
MAFIAS (Metadata and Associated Files Indexed and Archived Separately)
Data Architecture Pattern

Store structured metadata in primary database (SQLite/PostgreSQL)
Organize unstructured media in separate /attachments/ directory
Maintain file-to-record mapping for unified presentation
Implement clean separation between data and media layers
Support non-Latin character encodings (e.g., UTF-8 for Japanese, Chinese, Vietnamese) in metadata and file naming

/project
â”œâ”€â”€ database.db          # Structured metadata
â”œâ”€â”€ /attachments/        # Media files organized by record ID
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ /record_1/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ /record_2/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ /uploads/

SBMF (Side Bars & Main Frame)
UI Layout Pattern

Sidebar: Fixed-width navigation (250px expanded, 60px collapsed)
Main Frame: Flexible content area with responsive grid/flex layouts
Collapsible Navigation: Toggle button with hamburger icon
Responsive Behavior: Auto-collapse on mobile (<768px)
Unicode Support: Render non-Latin characters correctly in navigation and content

CRYSTAL Framework
Visual Design System

Clear Whitespace: Generous margins (40px desktop, 16px mobile)
Refined Minimalism: Single font family (Inter/Roboto/Noto Sans for non-Latin scripts), limited weights
Yielding Transparency: Frosted-glass panels with backdrop-filter: blur(12px)
Soft Shadows: Minimal elevation (rgba(0,0,0,0.08))
Transparent Backgrounds: Semi-transparent surfaces (rgba values)
Aesthetic Typography: Scaled font sizes (16px body, 24px H1, 18px H3)
Luminous Color Accents: Vibrant soft-green (#2AB67D) primary palette
Non-Latin Font Support: Use Noto Sans for Japanese, Chinese, Vietnamese, and other non-Latin scripts

RSR (Requirements, Setup, Run - OneClick Windows Deployment)
Zero-Configuration Windows Deployment Pattern

Automated Environment: One-click Windows setup with intelligent dependency resolution
Windows-Optimized: Native .bat launcher with Windows-specific optimizations
Self-Healing Installation: Automatic error detection and recovery mechanisms
Progressive Feedback: Real-time installation progress with animated Windows CLI indicators
Intelligent Defaults: Pre-configured settings optimized for Windows environment
Windows Integration: Desktop shortcuts, Start Menu entries, and system notifications
Unicode Handling: Support non-Latin characters in file paths and configuration files

RSR Windows Implementation Components:
/project
â”œâ”€â”€ run.bat                 # Windows OneClick launcher (primary entry point)
â”œâ”€â”€ setup.py               # Automated Windows installation orchestrator
â”œâ”€â”€ requirements.txt       # Python dependencies with Windows-compatible versions
â”œâ”€â”€ windows_installer.py   # Windows-specific installation utilities
â”œâ”€â”€ config/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ default.json       # Default application configuration with request timeout settings
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ database.sql       # Initial database schema
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ sample_data.json   # Optional demo data
â”œâ”€â”€ scripts/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ health_check.py    # Windows system validation
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ port_finder.py     # Available port detection
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ cleanup.py         # Uninstall/reset utilities
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ windows_utils.py   # Windows-specific helper functions
â””â”€â”€ README_WINDOWS.md      # Windows-specific setup guide

OneClick Windows Experience Flow:

Windows Environment Check: Python installation detection, Windows version compatibility
Virtual Environment Setup: Windows venv creation with CMD/PowerShell compatibility
Windows-Optimized Dependencies: Pip installation with Windows-specific packages and wheels
Database Initialization: SQLite setup with Windows file path handling and UTF-8 encoding
Windows Configuration: Config generation with Windows-specific paths, settings, and request timeout limits
Windows Service Launch: Application startup with Windows process management
Windows Integration: Browser auto-launch, system tray notification, desktop shortcut creation
Windows Monitoring: Task Manager integration and Windows event logging

Advanced Windows RSR Features:

Windows Port Discovery: Netstat integration for intelligent port selection (5000-5010)
Windows Browser Integration: Registry-based default browser detection and launch
Windows Dependency Caching: AppData local cache for offline installations
Windows Event Logging: Native Windows event log integration for debugging
Windows Error Recovery: Windows-specific error codes and suggested fixes
Windows Resource Monitoring: WMI integration for memory/CPU tracking
Windows Multi-Instance: Named pipe communication for multiple app instances
Windows Installer Package: Optional MSI package generation for enterprise deployment
Windows Auto-Start: Registry entries for automatic startup on Windows boot
Windows Security Integration: Windows Defender exclusions and UAC handling

Operational Frameworks
CRUD + OSEI Operations
Data Management Pattern

CRUD: Create, Read, Update, Delete with input validation
OSEI: Open (display), Save (create/update), Export (JSON), Import (JSON)
Implement transaction safety and rollback capabilities
Provide batch operations for efficiency
Support non-Latin character input and display in all operations

MEI (Media Embed/Insert)
Media Management Pattern

Support multiple formats: Images (PNG, JPG), Audio (MP3), Documents (PDF)
Embed media as HTML tags directly in text fields
Secure upload handling with file type validation
Automatic thumbnail generation for images
Handle non-Latin filenames and metadata correctly

ADE (Add, Delete, Edit Fields)
Dynamic Schema Management

Runtime field addition/removal per record
Store dynamic fields as JSON in flexible schema
Provide field type validation and constraints
Support field templates and presets
Allow non-Latin characters in field names and values

MTT + GLTT-DFSF (Multiple Tab Tiers + Grid/List/Thumbnails/Table views)
Interface Navigation Pattern

MTT: Horizontal tab navigation above main content (max 6 tabs per tier)
GLTT-DFSF: Multiple view modes with Dynamic Fuzzy matching, Sorting, Filtering
Real-time search with debounced input
Advanced filtering with multiple criteria
Support non-Latin character search and filtering
Include settings tab for configuring request timeout and response timeout limits

Implementation Standards
Color Palette Specification
Strictly adhere to this vibrant, high-contrast palette:

Typography Standards

Font Family: Inter or Roboto for Latin, Noto Sans for non-Latin scripts (e.g., Japanese, Chinese, Vietnamese)
Font Weights: Regular (400), Bold (700) only
Font Sizes: Body (16px), H1 (24px), H3 (18px), Tabs (16px)
Contrast: WCAG 2.1 AA compliance minimum

Responsive Design Requirements

Breakpoints: Mobile (<768px), Tablet (768px-1024px), Desktop (>1024px)
Sidebar Behavior: Auto-collapse on mobile, manual toggle on desktop
Content Stacking: Vertical stacking on mobile with 16px minimum padding
Touch Targets: Minimum 44px for mobile interactions
Non-Latin Text Rendering: Ensure proper rendering of non-Latin scripts across all breakpoints

Security & Performance Standards

Input Sanitization: Validate all user inputs, escape outputs, including non-Latin characters
File Upload Security: Type validation, size limits, virus scanning, non-Latin filename handling
Database Security: Parameterized queries, transaction management, UTF-8 encoding
Performance: Lazy loading, pagination, caching strategies
Error Handling: Graceful degradation, user-friendly error messages
Asynchronous Processing: Backend processing and server response handling must not block UI operations, allowing parallel user tasks

Development Workflow
File Structure Template
/project
â”œâ”€â”€ run.bat              # Windows OneClick launcher (MAIN ENTRY POINT)
â”œâ”€â”€ setup.py             # RSR Windows deployment orchestrator
â”œâ”€â”€ requirements.txt     # Windows-compatible pinned dependencies
â”œâ”€â”€ windows_installer.py # Windows-specific installation utilities
â”œâ”€â”€ app.py              # Main application entry
â”œâ”€â”€ /config/

â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ database.sql    # Database schema
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ sample_data.json # Demo data (optional)
â”œâ”€â”€ /scripts/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ health_check.py # Windows system validation
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ port_finder.py  # Windows port discovery
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ cleanup.py      # Windows cleanup utilities
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ windows_utils.py # Windows-specific helpers
â”œâ”€â”€ /templates/          
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ base.html       # Base template with SBMF layout

Code Quality Standards

Documentation: Comprehensive docstrings and inline comments
Naming: Descriptive variable/function names following convention, supporting non-Latin comments
Modularity: Separate concerns into distinct modules/components
Testing: Unit tests for core functionality, including non-Latin character handling
Version Control: Meaningful commit messages, feature branching

API Design Patterns
# RESTful endpoint structure
GET    /                 # Main application page
GET    /api/records      # Retrieve records with pagination
POST   /api/records      # Create new record
PUT    /api/records/<id> # Update existing record  
DELETE /api/records/<id> # Delete record
POST   /api/upload       # Handle media uploads
GET    /api/export       # Export data
POST   /api/import       # Import data

windows_installer.py Implementation
#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
Windows-Specific Installation and Integration Utilities
Handles Windows shortcuts, registry entries, and system integration
"""

import os
import sys
import json
import sqlite3
import socket
import subprocess
import winreg
import win32com.client
from pathlib import Path
import psutil

class WindowsInstaller:
    def __init__(self):
        self.project_root = Path(__file__).parent
        self.config_dir = self.project_root / "config"
        self.database_path = self.project_root / "database.db"
        self.app_name = "OneClick Application"
        
    def find_available_port(self, start_port=5000, max_attempts=10):
        """Find available port using Windows netstat integration"""
        import subprocess
        
        # Get active ports using Windows netstat
        result = subprocess.run(['netstat', '-an'], capture_output=True, text=True)
        active_ports = set()
        
        for line in result.stdout.split('\n'):
            if 'LISTENING' in line:
                try:
                    port = int(line.split(':')[-1].split()[0])
                    active_ports.add(port)
                except (ValueError, IndexError):
                    continue
        
        # Find first available port
        for port in range(start_port, start_port + max_attempts):
            if port not in active_ports:
                return port
                
        raise RuntimeError("No available ports found in Windows environment")
    
    def create_desktop_shortcut(self):
        """Create Windows desktop shortcut"""
        desktop = Path.home() / "Desktop"
        shortcut_path = desktop / f"{self.app_name}.lnk"
        
        shell = win32com.client.Dispatch("WScript.Shell")
        shortcut = shell.CreateShortcut(str(shortcut_path))
        shortcut.Targetpath = str(self.project_root / "run.bat")
        shortcut.WorkingDirectory = str(self.project_root)
        shortcut.IconLocation = str(self.project_root / "static" / "favicon.ico")
        shortcut.Description = f"Launch {self.app_name}"
        shortcut.save()
        
        print(f"âœ… Desktop shortcut created: {shortcut_path}")
    
    def register_file_associations(self):
        """Register Windows file associations for project files"""
        try:
            # Register .app file extension
            with winreg.CreateKey(winreg.HKEY_CURRENT_USER, r"Software\Classes\.appproject") as key:
                winreg.SetValue(key, "", winreg.REG_SZ, "OneClickApp")
            
            with winreg.CreateKey(winreg.HKEY_CURRENT_USER, r"Software\Classes\OneClickApp") as key:
                winreg.SetValue(key, "", winreg.REG_SZ, "OneClick Application Project")
                
            print("âœ… Windows file associations registered")
        except Exception as e:
            print(f"âš ï¸  File association registration failed: {e}")
    
    def setup_windows_firewall(self, port):
        """Configure Windows Firewall exception for the application"""
        try:
            cmd = [
                'netsh', 'advfirewall', 'firewall', 'add', 'rule',
                f'name={self.app_name}',
                'dir=in', 'action=allow', 'protocol=TCP',
                f'localport={port}'
            ]
            subprocess.run(cmd, check=True, capture_output=True)
            print(f"âœ… Windows Firewall exception added for port {port}")
        except subprocess.CalledProcessError:
            print(f"âš ï¸  Firewall configuration requires Administrator privileges")
    
    def windows_health_check(self):
        """Comprehensive Windows system health check"""
        checks = [
            ("Windows Version", self.check_windows_version),
            ("Python Installation", self.check_python_windows),
            ("Virtual Environment", self.check_venv_windows),
            ("Windows Permissions", self.check_windows_permissions),
            ("Available Memory", self.check_windows_memory),
            ("Disk Space", self.check_windows_disk_space),
            ("Network Connectivity", self.check_windows_network)
        ]
        
        print("ğŸ¥ Windows Health Check Results:")
        print("=" * 50)
        
        for check_name, check_func in checks:
            try:
                result = check_func()
                print(f"âœ… {check_name}: {result}")
            except Exception as e:
                print(f"âŒ {check_name}: {e}")
                return False
        
        print("=" * 50)
        return True
    
    def check_windows_version(self):
        """Check Windows version compatibility"""
        import platform
        version = platform.platform()
        if "Windows-10" in version or "Windows-11" in version:
            return f"Compatible - {version}"
        else:
            raise Exception(f"Unsupported Windows version: {version}")
    
    def check_windows_memory(self):
        """Check available Windows memory"""
        memory = psutil.virtual_memory()
        available_gb = memory.available / (1024**3)
        if available_gb < 1:
            raise Exception(f"Low memory: {available_gb:.1f}GB available")
        return f"{available_gb:.1f}GB available"

if __name__ == "__main__":
    installer = WindowsInstaller()
    
    if len(sys.argv) > 1:
        command = sys.argv[1]
        if command == "create_shortcuts":
            installer.create_desktop_shortcut()
        elif command == "health_check":
            if not installer.windows_health_check():
                sys.exit(1)
        elif command == "firewall_setup":
            port = int(sys.argv[2]) if len(sys.argv) > 2 else 5000
            installer.setup_windows_firewall(port)
    else:
        print("Windows Installer - Available commands:")
        print("  create_shortcuts - Create desktop shortcuts")
        print("  health_check    - Windows system validation")
        print("  firewall_setup  - Configure Windows Firewall")

 ğŸ—„ï¸ Database Schema

```sql

 ğŸš€ Core Features Implementation

 ğŸ“ File Structure Requirements

```
flask-issue-tracker/

prompts.content:

prompts.title: Simplified Flask Application Prompt
prompts.content:
Simplified Flask Application Prompt
Objective
Develop a modular, user-friendly Flask web application with essential functionality, optimized for Windows deployment, focusing on simplicity, modularity, and core features. Adhere to DRY, KISS, and SOLID principles, ensuring maintainability and extensibility while supporting non-Latin character encodings (e.g., UTF-8 for Japanese, Chinese, Vietnamese).
Core Requirements
Functionality

CRUD Operations: Implement Create, Read, Update, Delete with input validation and transaction safety.
Media Management: Support image (PNG, JPG), audio (MP3), and document (PDF) uploads with secure handling, thumbnail generation for images, and non-Latin filename support.
Dynamic Schema: Allow runtime addition, deletion, and editing of fields, stored as JSON, with validation and non-Latin character support.
Navigation & Views: Provide tab-based navigation (max 6 tabs) with grid, list, and table view modes, including real-time search, sorting, and filtering with non-Latin character support.
Data Export/Import: Support JSON-based export and import of records.
Settings: Include a settings tab for configuring request and response timeout limits.

User Interface

Layout: Use a responsive layout with a collapsible sidebar (auto-collapse on mobile <768px) and a main content area.
Design: Apply a minimal design with a single font (Inter or Noto Sans for non-Latin scripts), a vibrant soft-green primary color (#2AB67D), and WCAG 2.1 AA-compliant contrast.
Responsive Design: Support mobile (<768px), tablet (768px-1024px), and desktop (>1024px) breakpoints with proper non-Latin text rendering.

Technical Standards

Framework: Use Flask with SQLite for data storage.
Modularity: Organize code into distinct modules (e.g., routes, models, utilities) for easy extension and testing.
Security: Implement input sanitization, parameterized queries, file type validation, and UTF-8 encoding.
Performance: Use lazy loading, pagination, and caching for efficiency.
Asynchronous Processing: Ensure non-blocking UI with asynchronous backend operations.

Windows Deployment

One-Click Setup: Provide a run.bat script for automated Windows setup, including:
Python and virtual environment validation.
Dependency installation via requirements.txt.
Database initialization with UTF-8 support.
Automatic browser launch to http://localhost:<port>.


Portability: Minimize files while ensuring functionality, with a modular structure for easy maintenance.

File Structure
/project
â”œâ”€â”€ run.bat              # Windows launcher
â”œâ”€â”€ app.py               # Main Flask application
â”œâ”€â”€ requirements.txt     # Python dependencies
â”œâ”€â”€ /templates/          # HTML templates
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ base.html        # Base layout
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ index.html       # Main page
â”œâ”€â”€ /static/             # Static assets
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ css/style.css    # Stylesheet
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ js/script.js     # Client-side scripts
â”œâ”€â”€ /models/             # Data models
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ models.py        # Database models
â”œâ”€â”€ /utils/              # Utility functions
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ utils.py         # Shared utilities
â”œâ”€â”€ /attachments/        # Media storage
â””â”€â”€ database.db          # SQLite database

API Endpoints

GET / - Main application page
GET /api/records - Retrieve records (with pagination)
POST /api/records - Create record
PUT /api/records/<id> - Update record
DELETE /api/records/<id> - Delete record
POST /api/upload - Upload media
GET /api/export - Export data as JSON
POST /api/import - Import JSON data

Acceptance Criteria

All CRUD operations are functional with non-Latin character support.
Media uploads and dynamic schema management work seamlessly.
Navigation and view modes (grid/list/table) support search, sort, and filter.
Export/import functionality handles JSON correctly.
UI is responsive, accessible, and visually consistent.
Windows deployment via run.bat is automated and user-friendly.
Code is modular, documented, and adheres to DRY, KISS, SOLID principles.
Security and performance measures are implemented.

Notes

Prioritize simplicity and modularity to reduce development complexity.
Ensure all modules are independent for easy testing and extension.
Support non-Latin characters in all inputs, outputs, and file handling.
Keep the file count minimal while maintaining full functionality.

       â€¢  Compare [COMPANY] to competitors. 
       â€¢  List 5+ growth or profit levers they havenâ€™t used yet. 
Prioritize: 
       â€¢  Score each idea: Impact: Revenue/profit upside (1â€“5) Feasibility: Ease + speed (1â€“5)

prompts.title: Strategy Analysis
prompts.content:
Professional Strategy Analysis Prompt for Large Language Models
You are a highly skilled professional strategist and entrepreneur with expertise in strategic analysis. Your task is to create a comprehensive prompt for a large language model (e.g., ChatGPT) to conduct a robust strategy analysis for a given business context using a combination of strategic frameworks. Each framework has unique strengths and purposes, suited to different scenarios. Since a single framework rarely ensures a thorough analysis, you must recommend optimal combinations of frameworks to deliver actionable insights. Below is the business context and a detailed list of frameworks with their purposes, usage, strengths, and weaknesses. Your output should include recommended framework combinations tailored to the business context, along with guidance on how to apply them for maximum impact.
Business Context
{{[[Insert Business Context Here]]}}
Strategic Frameworks
3C Analysis

Purpose: Identify strategic opportunities by analyzing Customer, Competitor, and Company.
Usage: Conduct micro/macro customer research, map competitor strengths and threats, and benchmark internal capabilities.
Strength: Balances focus on market demand, competitive landscape, and internal readiness; prioritizes customer value.
Weakness: May overlook stakeholders like partners or channels unless extended (e.g., to 4C).

SWOT Analysis

Purpose: Identify internal Strengths and Weaknesses alongside external Opportunities and Threats.
Usage: Cross-reference S/W with O/T (Cross-SWOT) to develop offensive or defensive strategies.
Strength: Intuitive framework linking internal factors to market dynamics, yielding actionable strategies.
Weakness: Risks superficial analysis without prioritization; subjective interpretation of S/W.

PEST Analysis

Purpose: Assess macro-environmental factors: Political, Economic, Social, Technological.
Usage: Conduct workshops or research to forecast external trends and their impacts.
Strength: Provides a holistic view of industry-shaping forces; encourages proactive responses.
Weakness: Lacks linkage to competitive dynamics or internal capabilities; may produce excessive detail.

3M/5M/7M (Resource Frameworks)

Purpose: Inventory critical resourcesâ€”Men, Materials, Money (plus Information, Market, Method, Measurement, Machines).
Usage: Diagnose resource gaps in operations by expanding from 3M to 5M/7M.
Strength: Ensures comprehensive resource planning; highlights critical inputs.
Weakness: Does not prioritize resource allocation or strategic focus.

7S Framework

Purpose: Align Strategy, Structure, Systems (hard elements) with Shared Values, Skills, Staff, Style (soft elements).
Usage: Assess organizational alignment across all seven elements to identify inconsistencies.
Strength: Balances culture and capabilities with formal structures; identifies change levers.
Weakness: Soft elements are hard to measure; changing soft elements requires long-term effort.

VRIO Framework

Purpose: Evaluate resources for sustained competitive advantage based on Value, Rarity, Inimitability, Organization.
Usage: Classify assets/capabilities as competitive disadvantages, temporary advantages, or sustainable advantages.
Strength: Links resource analysis to long-term strategy; enhances internal audits.
Weakness: Focus on existing resources may undervalue innovation or ecosystem dynamics.

Porterâ€™s Five Forces

Purpose: Assess industry attractiveness via New Entrants, Substitutes, Supplier Power, Buyer Power, and Rivalry.
Usage: Evaluate market entry or competitive positioning; set investment thresholds.
Strength: Deepens understanding of competitive structure; informs margin and barrier assessments.
Weakness: Static analysis may miss rapid technological shifts or collaborative ecosystems.

Lanchesterâ€™s Laws

Purpose: Guide tactical decisions for weak vs. strong players by modeling force concentration.
Usage: Weak firms target niche battles; strong firms leverage broad resources.
Strength: Provides clear resource allocation rules based on relative scale.
Weakness: Oversimplifies complex markets; ignores intangibles like brand loyalty.

Competitive Strategy Positioning

Purpose: Select leadership in Cost, Differentiation, or Focus to secure competitive advantage.
Usage: Map strategic direction by target breadth and advantage type; align activities.
Strength: Offers clear strategic taxonomy; ensures value-chain coherence.
Weakness: Risks â€œstuck in the middleâ€ without commitment; may overlook hybrid strategies.

PPM (BCG Matrix)

Purpose: Prioritize resource allocation across business units using Market Growth vs. Relative Share.
Usage: Classify units as Stars, Cash Cows, Question Marks, or Dogs to guide invest/harvest/divest decisions.
Strength: Simplifies portfolio management and cash-flow planning.
Weakness: Ignores synergies, scale asymmetries, and qualitative factors; arbitrary thresholds.

Ansoffâ€™s Growth Matrix

Purpose: Identify growth strategies via Market Penetration, Market Development, Product Development, Diversification.
Usage: Assess risk by combining existing/new products with existing/new markets.
Strength: Clarifies risk levels; structures growth planning.
Weakness: Omits execution challenges and evolving customer needs; underestimates diversification risks.

Value Chain

Purpose: Analyze Primary and Support Activities to identify value creation and cost drivers.
Usage: Target high-impact activities for improvement or outsourcing based on margin contributions.
Strength: Links operations to customer value and costs; supports process optimization.
Weakness: Granular analysis can be complex; interdependencies may be hard to trace.

Balanced Scorecard (BSC)

Purpose: Translate strategy into measurable objectives across Financial, Customer, Internal Process, and Learning & Growth perspectives.
Usage: Develop strategic maps, define Key Success Factors, and track KPIs.
Strength: Aligns non-financial metrics with financial goals; promotes balanced performance.
Weakness: Complex implementation; too many metrics may dilute focus.

Business Model Canvas

Purpose: Map nine building blocks (Customer Segments, Value Propositions, Channels, etc.) to design or analyze business models.
Usage: Prototype/test new models or document existing ones; align teams.
Strength: Simplifies complex models; fosters creativity and dialogue.
Weakness: Lacks depth on execution and financials; may oversimplify complex businesses.

Task

Analyze the Business Context: Interpret the provided business context to identify key strategic challenges, objectives, and market dynamics.
Recommend Framework Combinations: Propose 2â€“3 optimal combinations of the listed frameworks, tailored to the business context. For each combination:
Specify which frameworks to use and in what sequence.
Explain why the combination is effective, addressing how each framework complements the others to mitigate weaknesses and maximize strengths.
Provide a brief step-by-step guide on how to apply the combination (e.g., data inputs, analysis process, expected outputs).


Deliver Actionable Insights: Ensure the output provides clear, prioritized recommendations for strategic actions based on the combined framework analysis.
Format the Response: Structure the response professionally with clear headings (e.g., Business Context Analysis, Recommended Combinations, Application Steps, Strategic Recommendations) and concise, actionable language.

prompts.title: Commercial RA
prompts.content:
CONTRACT RISK ASSESSMENT AND COMPLIANCE REVIEW
Please conduct a comprehensive legal and commercial risk analysis of the attached contract document against our established compliance framework. Your assessment should include:
1. COMPLIANCE ANALYSIS
Cross-reference all contract terms against our legal guardrails database 
Identify any regulatory violations, policy breaches, or non-compliance issues 
Flag terms that conflict with CBRE's standard contractual practices 
2. COMMERCIAL RISK EVALUATION
Analyze contract provisions that may be commercially disadvantageous to CBRE 
Identify clauses with unfavorable financial implications, liability exposures, or operational constraints 
Assess terms that could impact CBRE's competitive position or service delivery capabilities 
3. RISK CATEGORIZATION Classify all identified issues using the following risk matrix:
CRITICAL: Immediate legal/financial exposure requiring urgent attention 
HIGH: Significant commercial disadvantage or compliance concern 
MEDIUM: Moderate risk requiring negotiation or mitigation 
LOW: Minor issues for monitoring or future consideration 
4. DELIVERABLE FORMAT
Executive summary of key findings 
Detailed risk register with specific clause references 
Recommended actions for each identified risk level 
Suggested contract amendments or negotiation points 
Please ensure all findings are supported by specific contract language citations and applicable legal/policy references.

<Terms and conditions to be revised are shown as below>
[[Terms and conditions]]

prompts.title: Commercial RA (Solutions)
prompts.content:
Based on the provided risk analysis, please generate new or revised contractual terms and conditions that align with existing contract frameworks. Utilize Contract Template LAFM-EJ in the project folder, which has clause and terms in favor of CBRE. Ensure the proposed modifications adhere to the following requirements:

1. Maintain consistency with established language patterns and terminology used in the original contract. Mimicking the original language style.

2. Replicate the linguistic style, tone, and structural conventions of the existing terms

3. Format all new additions or modifications using bold italics to clearly distinguish them from original content

4. Preserve the maximum amount of original contractual language possible

5. Implement only essential changes necessary to address identified risks

Please prioritize minimal intervention while ensuring comprehensive risk mitigation through strategically placed contractual enhancements.

prompts.content:

Your task is to (1) learn the projectâ€™s Japanese contractual writing style from the provided templates, then (2) render the new content into Japanese using that exact style, and (3) output parallel English/Japanese lines in a simple HTML-canvasâ€“friendly text format. Inputs â€¢ Style Corpus (Japanese/English templates): Please refer to Projects Documents â€¢ Source Content (English or mixed): [[Paste content here]] Step-by-step Instructions 1. Style Study (Japanese Contractual Register) o Read all attached project templates/files (JP & EN) to learn: ï‚§ Sentence architecture, register, and tone (e.g., formal keigo vs. plain; passive voice; fixed legalisms). ï‚§ Terminology mappings (e.g., â€œdemised premises,â€ â€œlien,â€ â€œset-off,â€ â€œfixtures,â€ â€œindemnity,â€ â€œliability cap,â€ etc.). ï‚§ Clause openers, modal verbs, hedging/limitations, definitions, numbering, punctuation norms, and date/number formats. o Derive a style sheet (mentally) including preferred JP terms, set phrases, and formatting patterns. o If the templates conflict, give priority to the most recent or most official CBRE/Client templates you find in the corpus. 2. Parallel Output (Canvas-HTML-friendly) o Output paragraph by paragraph, where each paragraph is a single line containing: ï‚§ English first (black), then a space, then a forward slash /, then Japanese (blue). o Wrap each language chunk in spans that can be drawn or parsed for HTML canvas rendering: ï‚§ English: â€¦
